div.p:
In the odd little case which accompa
nies this letter you will find two
little drawings - they are done by
MrsEdgeworth - one is the por
traitportrait taken from the life of the Snow
Woman whose history you republished
for young readers last Christmas -
If you think that it would add to the
interest of the story to know that it
is founded on fact - that it is so far
so far that a woman & her children
were actually buried & half famished
under the snow, I would certify
the fact for you in a preface to your
young readers next Christmas if
you would have the portrait of the
poor woman engraved for a frontis
piecefrontispiece -
The other drawing - the chimney
sweeper and the owl - this was taken
from the life a few days ago - And it
has just occurred to me that I could
work the incident to which it refers
into a continuation or second volume of the History of poor Bob
the chimney sweeper which you thought
it worthwhile to reprint - I think I could
furnish about 40 or or 80 pages so as to
make Poor Bob whom I wish to raise by
his own exertions into Happy Bob
a fit companion for the Snow woman
as to length -
I would give you the end of the story
if you would have Mrs E's little sketches
drawings well engraved for frontis
piece the story- I know engravings
by good hands are very expensive &
I am not sure that you would find
it worth your while to have these well
engraved and I must distinctly say
that I would rather not have them
done at all than done by any inferior
hand- They must be by some of the
hands employed in Sir Walter Scotts
Waverly novels or his poetical works
Tell me frankly whether it be
worth your while to accept of my condi
tions - Of course I would wish to have
a few copies of the engravings for my
self and my friends - but for the number
I make no bargaining I should leave
that entirely to your own liberality
- my object is plainly to have the drawings
well engraved
Answer me without delay
- because if you should not like to accept
My conditions I would turn my
story another way & not make it a
Continuation or Sequel of Poor Bob -
And if you do accept I should sit down
& write Happy Bob directly - before the ideas
go out of my head
I beg at all events that you
will take care of the drawings & that
you will _ if they are to be engraved Ad
vise that they should not be spoilt in the
engravers hands - And if you return
them to me immediately let them
be packed in the same little case
in which I have packed them
Mr. Wood (Secy. of the Treasury) will
frank the packet to me whenever you
apply to him & by the same means
send your answer to this letter
div.closer:
I am Dr. Sir
Yours sincerely
Maria Edgeworth
